info: (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take interdisciplinary coursework in ecology and environment policy. For Spring term, this is combined with fieldwork and a directed research project.

name: STDABRD 309. CGIS: Frontiers Abroad - Geology and Earth Systems Science in Auckland and Christchurch, New Zealand
info: (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Frontiers Abroad leads undergraduate fieldwork and research programs in earth and environmental sciences.

name: STDABRD 310. CGIS: International Development and French Language in Dakar, Senegal
info: Minimum 3.0 GPA overall and in French classes; minimum 3 semesters college-level French or equivalent. (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: All students are required to take at least one French language course, based on students' command of the French language, and one Wolof course; the most predominant local language. In addition students can enroll in a minimum of three three-credit courses from among those offered at UCAD and IFE and those specially arranged for program participants.

name: STDABRD 311. CGIS: Psychology and Research in Madrid, Spain
info: Preference given to students with two semesters college-level Spanish or more. (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: During the 6-week summer program in Madrid, students will take Introduction to Biological Psychology (3 credits, equivalent to Psych 230 at UM) and Research Laboratory in Psychology (3 credits) for a total of 6 credits. This program is offered in partnership with the prestigious Fundacion Ortega-Maranon in Madrid and the University of Minnesota's Department of Psychology.

name: STDABRD 312. CGIS: Language and Culture in Madrid, Spain
info: 5 semesters of college-level Spanish. (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in two area studies courses, taught in Spanish, at the IES Madrid Center for a total of 6 credits at the 300 level.

name: STDABRD 313. CGIS: Summer Moroccan Studies in Rabat, Morocco
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: The Summer Moroccan Studies program is designed to provide students with a multifaceted academic analysis of Moroccan culture and history. Discuss the factors of Moroccan identity and the major issues of contemporary Moroccan society or examine the recent social and political changes in the Middle East and North Africa region.

name: STDABRD 314. CGIS: Summer Arabic Language in Rabat, Morocco
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in a Standard Modern Arabic Course and Colloquial Modern Arabic Language course.

name: STDABRD 315. CGIS: Wildlife Management Studies in Rhotia, Tanzania
info: (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: At the School for Field Studies field site in Tanzania students study wildlife ecology and behavior, explore resource management techniques in the East African ecosystem, evaluate the ecological and sociocultural impacts of cultural tourism in Tanzania, and perform directed research.

name: STDABRD 320. CGIS: Marine Resource Studies in The Turks and Caicos Islands
info: (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: At the School for Field Studies field site in Turks and Caicos students learn about tropical marine ecology, evaluate host country recourse management and policies, and practice field research skills in the tropical Western Atlantic.

name: STDABRD 325. CGIS: Chinese Studies in Shanghai, China
info: (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Beijing, China). Su. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Designed for students with interest in Chinese area studies and any level of study in Chinese language. The program provides an opportunity for in-depth learning about China from a broad perspective of topics. Required language study ensures linguistic and cultural connection with the area studies topics and optional internship placement.

name: STDABRD 330. CGIS: Budapest Semesters in Mathematics in Budapest, Hungary
info: (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in mathematics courses taught in English by Budapest Semesters in Mathematics (BSM) faculty.

name: STDABRD 332. CGIS: Central European Studies at Charles University in Prague, Czech Republic (UPCES)
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Prague, Czech Republic). F, W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students choose from a wide range of courses in the humanities and social sciences, taught in English. Students select four courses in addition to the required Czech language course.

name: STDABRD 336. CGIS: Central European Studies in Prague, Czech Republic (CIEE)
info: (1 - 15). May be elected 91 times for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students direct enroll as fulltime students in classes at Charles University and/or the Prague CIEE Study Center taught in English. 15-18 credits.

name: STDABRD 337. CGIS: Central European Studies Summer Program in Prague, Czech Republic
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students direct enroll as part-time or full-time students in classes at the Prague CIEE Study Center taught in English. 3-10 credits depending on which session or combination of sessions participants are enrolled in.

name: STDABRD 338. CGIS: Cross-Cultural Psychology in Prague, Czech Republic
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in this CET taught course for 3 credits. This course examines how cultural differences in developmental, social and educational areas affect individual behavior. It critically compares psychological theories and current research from specific countries and explores the critical thinking and intercultural competence in the framework of cross-cultural psychology.

name: STDABRD 339. CGIS: Peace and Conflict Studies in Serbia, Bosnia, and Kosovo
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take classes at the SIT Study Abroad center in Belgrade, Serbia focused on Conflict Studies in the Balkans. Students will also go on excursions to Bosnia-Herzegovina and Kosovo.

name: STDABRD 340. CGIS: Liberal Arts in Athens, Greece
info: (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Administered by CYA, students take courses in ancient, medieval, and modern Greek history, politics, literature, philosophy, and archaeology, as well as ancient and modern Greek language and Latin.

name: STDABRD 341. CGIS: Summer Study Abroad in Athens or the Greek Isles, Greece
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Administered by CYA, students study history, politics, writing, and sociology in sessions located throughout Greece, including Athens and the Greek Isles.

name: STDABRD 343. CGIS: University Study in Japan - Hitotsubashi University (Tokyo)
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at Hitotsubashi University. Classes are taught in English; students with Japanese language proficiency may enroll in regular classes.

name: STDABRD 344. CGIS: Race, Culture, and Community in London, UK
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. May not be elected Pass/Fail. (London, England). Sp. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in two UM Faculty-led classes focusing on modern British society, culture and the arts, and will earn a total of six credits (three credits each class).

name: STDABRD 345. CGIS: University Study in Germany - University of Tuebingen
info: 3-4 semesters college-level German or equivalent. (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Tübingen, Germany). F, W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take an intensive German language course before enrolling directly in the University of Tuebingen.

name: STDABRD 346. CGIS: Advanced Russian Language and Culture in Russia
info: Minimum 4 semesters of college Russian, with average of B or better in language courses. (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Russia) F, W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: The C.V. Starr-Middlebury College School in Russia is designed for students at an intermediate to advanced level of Russian who wish to immerse themselves in the study of the Russian language and culture. Students will study in one of three distinct locations in Russia.

name: STDABRD 347. CGIS: University Study in Japan - Waseda University (Tokyo)
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at Waseda University. Classes are taught in English; students with Japanese language proficiency may enroll in regular classes.

name: STDABRD 349. CGIS: Language and Culture in Hikone, Japan
info: One year proficiency in Japanese. (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Hikone, Shiga, Japan). F, W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Administered by JCMU, this program offers Japanese language and area studies courses.

name: STDABRD 350. CGIS: European Union Summer Program in Freiburg, Germany
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take an introductory course on the European Union through this customized IES program in Germany.

name: STDABRD 351. CGIS: Academic Year in Freiburg, Germany
info: Minimum two years of college-level German. (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Freiburg, Germany). F, W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at the University of Freiburg as well as classes offered by the AYF program.

name: STDABRD 352. CGIS: University Study in Singapore - National University of Singapore
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at the National University of Singapore (NUS). A full range of classes is available.

name: STDABRD 353. CGIS: Classical Studies (ICCS) in Rome, Italy
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Rome, Italy). F, W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Administered by ICCS, students take courses in classics, classical history, or archaeology.

name: STDABRD 354. CGIS: Metropolitan Studies in Berlin, Germany
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take coursework in the humanities and social sciences, in subjects such as gender studies, sustainability, film, and identity. Students take a required German language course.

name: STDABRD 355. CGIS: Advanced French Language in Paris, France
info: 5 semesters of college level French or equivalent. (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at various Paris institutions as well as classes offered by the Middlebury program.

name: STDABRD 356. CGIS: Tropical Island Biodiversity Studies in Isla Colon, Panama
info: (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students explore and learn about marine and rainforest ecosystems while studying impacts of tourism and development on the Caribbean's unique island habitats. Participants learn about environmental policies, sustainable tourism, and conservation. Interaction with locals offers a first-hand understanding of how they depend on tourism and natural resources for a livelihood.

name: STDABRD 357. CGIS: Sustainable Food Systems and Ecology in Chiang Mai, Thailand
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take one course while on-site and examine sustainable agriculture in Thailand with the larger framework of sustainable development and ecology. The course is a mix of seminars and field-based experiential learning focusing on global food systems and the ecological and cultural context of food systems in Thailand.

name: STDABRD 358. CGIS: Conservation and Development Studies in Siem Reap, Cambodia
info: 1 college-level course in Ecology, Biology, or Environmental Science/Studies. (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students travel across various regions of Cambodia to explore development and conservation challenges throughout the country, in addition to brief exploration of these themes in nearby communities in Vietnam. Summer students will also study conservation challenges and ethics while they focus on the ecology and conservation of the Asian elephant.

name: STDABRD 359. CGIS: Community Public Health in Khon Kaen, Thailand
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: In this course students will introduce students to performing community health assessments in Thai communities. Participants will gain practical knowledge from local healthcare providers and community organizations. Participants gain a view of health care and practices from the lens of the specific cultural, social, economic, and political context in Thailand.

name: STDABRD 360. CGIS: Climate Studies in Puerto Natales, Chile
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students study impacts of climate change, diverse ecosystems, and conservation in one of the world's most iconic natural regions. The mountains, glaciers and fjords of Patagonia serve as a classroom for students to do field work and conduct research examining ecology and geologic systems, sustainability, and unique species of Patagonia.

name: STDABRD 361. CGIS: Roots, Culture, and Rhythms in Havana, Cuba
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in a 3 credits. Explore and examine the roots of Afro Cuban culture through music, dance and visual art. Join UM students and faculty in Havana, as they investigate the Afro-Cuban influences in Cuban culture through engaged discussion, historical walks through Old Havana, workshops and performances in Afro-Cuban music and dance, as it relates to religion, popular culture and identity.

name: STDABRD 362. CGIS: Intensive Russian Language and Culture in St. Petersburg, Russia
info: Minimum 4 semesters-college Russian (oral proficiency score of Intermediate or better). (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (St. Petersburg, Russia). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Administered by CIEE, this program offers Russian language and area studies courses. This program is designed for students with two years of college-level Russian who wish to improve their proficiency with the Russian language. This is an intensive program that focuses on all language skills and includes Russian culture classes and field trips/excursions.

name: STDABRD 363. CGIS: Liberal Arts in Santiago, Chile
info: Successful completion of one of the following courses, or equivalent (with approval from your CGIS Intercultural Programs Advisor): SPANISH 275 & 276, or SPANISH 277, or RCLANG 324 Spanish language course within the past year recommended. (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Santiago, Chile). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Program participants take classes alongside Chilean students at the host university, La Pontifical Universidad Catolica. Administered jointly with the University of Wisconsin.

name: STDABRD 364. CGIS: University Study in the UK - University of Sussex
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Brighton, England). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at the University of Sussex in Brighton. A full range of classes is available.

name: STDABRD 365. CGIS: Development and Globalization in Khon Kaen, Thailand
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Administered by CIEE, students work on group projects and learn about development and globalization from both an academic and a grassroots community level and its overall effects on a developing nation.

name: STDABRD 366. CGIS: Public Health in Santiago, Dominican Republic
info: College-level coursework in public health recommended. Minimum four semesters college-level Spanish, fulfilled by one of the following or equivalent: SPANISH 230, SPANISH 232, or RCLANG 294, RCLANG 314. (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic). Su. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Designed for students with an interest in Spanish language, medicine, and public health. This program examines a range of pre-professional healthcare issues, and provides students with the opportunity to engage with local patients and medical staff through a health practicum and clinical rotation.

name: STDABRD 367. CGIS: Global Public Health in New Delhi, India
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Customized program in Public Health for UM students. Students will participate in one course for UM credit while participating in excursions and visits to local NGOs and health facilities. Combines policy, culture, gender, caste, class, and politics to deliver a multi-dimensional understanding of global public health.

name: STDABRD 368. CGIS: Intensive Hindi and Urdu Language in New Delhi, India
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students participate in intensive language learning for the full program in Hindi or Urdu language.

name: STDABRD 369. CGIS: Language and Culture in Varanasi, India
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students participate in culture courses in India while studying at various levels of Hindi language, and also participate in a directed cultural field study. Opportunities to study Urdu are also possible.

name: STDABRD 370. CGIS: Sustainable Development Studies in Chiang Mai, Thailand
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students focus on sustainable development throughout Thailand. Collaboration with locals enhances this field-based learning. Students explore farming practices and resource management and take four courses (18 credits). The program involves trekking and camping in remote regions and snorkeling and sea kayaking in coastal areas. Students live with local host families.

name: STDABRD 371. CGIS: Gender and Public Health in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students explore public health and globalization issues in Vietnam and learn how Vietnam is addressing poverty, HIV/AIDS, and other challenges. Participants examine health issues women face and how gender roles affect health. Reproductive health and sex work are examined as well as their relationship to poverty, inequality, and employment.

name: STDABRD 372. CGIS: Development Studies in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students study impacts of development and how this alters communities. While engaging with locals, students see how development is changing Vietnamese society, while gaining insight into how these changes affect individuals. Students explore issues such as social justice, environmental degradation, gender roles, resource management, public health infrastructure, and colonialism.

name: STDABRD 373. CGIS: Environmental Studies in Paro, Bhutan
info: (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students will explore and learn about the rich culture, biodiversity, and mountain ecosystems of the Bhutanese Himalayas. Participants will learn about the challenges of maintaining rural lifestyles and study the issues of conservation and development. Students will also conduct directed research and go on treks and camping trips.

name: STDABRD 374. CGIS: University Study in South Korea - Yonsei University (Seoul)
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Seoul, South Korea). F, W, Su. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at Yonsei University. A full range of classes is available. Classes are taught in English; students with Korean language proficiency may enroll in regular classes.

name: STDABRD 376. CGIS: Summer at Yonsei - Seoul, South Korea
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take two to three courses as part of Yonsei University's International Summer School program. Courses are in English. The emphasis for this program is on Korean language and Korean studies, however students will also have the opportunity to choose from a range of humanities, social sciences, and science courses offered at Yonsei University.

name: STDABRD 381. CGIS: Advanced Italian Language in Bologna, Italy
info: Minimum 5 semesters college-level Italian or equivalent (Winter); Minimum 4 semesters college-level Italian or equivalent (Academic Year). (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students choose a combination of Bologna Consortial Studies Program (BCSP) courses and University of Bologna courses. All students are required to take one BCSP Advanced Grammar course. The program begins with a 4-week pre-session BCSP course, which integrates language and culture study, before university and regular semester BCSP courses begin.

name: STDABRD 382. CGIS: Language and Culture in Ferrara, Italy
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: This program is designed for students with little or no Italian language background with a strong interest in learning the Italian language and culture. Ferrara is a renaissance city in northeastern Italy, midway between Venice and Florence, and relatively unknown to tourists.

name: STDABRD 383. CGIS: Language and Culture in Rome, Italy
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: The Arcadia University Center for Italian Studies (AUCIS) is based in Rome. The program is connected with one of Rome's most dynamic and innovative universities, Universita degli Studi Roma Tre.

name: STDABRD 384. CGIS: Language and Culture in Rome, Italy - Internship Track
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at the Arcadia center in Rome, as well as classes offered at Universita degli Studi Roma Tre. In addition, students will complete an internship.

name: STDABRD 385. CGIS: Multidisciplinary Studies in Perugia, Italy
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in one or two 3-credit courses at the Umbra Institute for a variety of courses including archeology, art history, communication, psychology, education, Italian language and more during a 5 week period.

name: STDABRD 399. CGIS: European Union Summer Program in Amsterdam, Netherlands
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in IES taught course for 3 credits. Introduces the basic principles of the European Union; its institutions and the position of member states. The focus will seek to understand how the EU deals with current challenges of migration, climate change and enlargement and how policies are implemented and the impact on member states.

name: STDABRD 400. CGIS: Social Sciences in Amsterdam, the Netherlands
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in courses at the University of Amsterdam as well as classes offered by the CIEE program.

name: STDABRD 401. CGIS: Study Abroad in Scandinavia (DIS) in Copenhagen, Denmark
info: (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in one core course and several elective courses offered in a variety of disciplines and taught in English by Danish Institute for Study Abroad (DIS) faculty in Stockholm.

name: STDABRD 402. CGIS: Biodiversity & Development of the Amazon in Nauta, Peru
info: 1 college-level course in Ecology, Biology, or Environmental Science/Studies. (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students travel to the Amazon to explore current conservation efforts, various ecological patterns, and study the extraordinary biodiversity of the Amazon. Participants enroll in 5 required courses on-site, while completing directed research projects and becoming acquainted with local indigenous peoples.

name: STDABRD 403. CGIS: Quechua Langauge in Cusco, Peru
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in intensive Quechua language classes at Centro Tinku in Cusco, Peru. They will be placed in one of three Quechua language levels.

name: STDABRD 404. CGIS: International Development in Quito, Ecuador
info: Minimum 4 semesters college-level Spanish or equivalent (students must have taken Spanish within the last academic year or verify advanced level proficiency). (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students study international development in Ecuador while improving their Spanish language skills. They will also contribute through an internship or research project with a nonprofit organization while they are there.

name: STDABRD 405. CGIS: Brazilian Studies and Portuguese Language in Sao Paulo, Brazil
info: (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in Portuguese language classes plus electives taught in English by CET faculty in Sao Paulo and have the option to directly enroll in courses at a local Brazilian institution.

name: STDABRD 406. CGIS: Summer Study Abroad in Copenhagen, Denmark or Stockholm, Sweden (DIS)
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in one to three spring/summer courses offered in a variety of disciplines by Danish Institute for Study Abroad (DIS) faculty in Stockholm, Sweden; Copenhagen, Denmark; or both.

name: STDABRD 407. CGIS: Climate Change and the Artic in Isafjorour, Iceland
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take courses taught by local instructors at the SIT Center. Topics include climate modeling, changing ecosystems, research methods and ethics. Participants have the opportunity to research a topic of their choice to present at the end of the semester.

name: STDABRD 430. CGIS: Banking, Finance, and Social Responsibility in Nyon, Switzerland
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take classes at the SIT Study Abroad center in Nyon, Switzerland focused on banking, finance, social responsibility, and the French language.

name: STDABRD 431. CGIS: Food Security and Nutrition in Nyon, Switzerland
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take classes at the SIT Study Abroad center in Geneva and Nyon, Switzerland focused on food security, nutrition, and the French language.

name: STDABRD 432. CGIS: Global Health and Development Policy in Nyon, Switzerland
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take classes at the SIT Study Abroad center in Nyon, Switzerland focused on health, development policy, and the French language.

name: STDABRD 433. CGIS: International Studies and Multilateral Diplomacy in Geneva, Switzerland
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take classes at the SIT Study Abroad center in Geneva, Switzerland focused on international studies, multilateral diplomacy, and the French language.

name: STDABRD 434. CGIS: International Studies and Multilateral Diplomacy Summer Program in Geneva, Switzerland
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take classes at the SIT Study Abroad center in Geneva, Switzerland focused on international studies, multilateral diplomacy, and the French language.

name: STDABRD 435. CGIS: Traditional Health and Healthcare Systems in Antananarivo, Madagascar
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take classes at the SIT Study Abroad center in Antananarivo, Madagascar focused on traditional and healthcare systems.

name: STDABRD 436. CGIS: Peace and Conflict Studies in Gulu, Uganda and Kigali, Rwanda
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take classes at the SIT Study Abroad centers in Gulu, Uganda and Kigali, Rwanda focused on peace and conflict.

name: STDABRD 437. CGIS: Wildlife and Ecology in Kimana, Kenya
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Study Kenya's diverse wildlife and approaches to conservation. In the heart of the Great Rift Valley, explore how climate change and land use changes are negatively affecting ecosystems and those living in them. Research root causes of these changes and how different conservation strategies can benefit both humans and wildlife.

name: STDABRD 438. CGIS: Health and Community in Brazil, India, South Africa, and the U.S.
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take classes at the SIT Study Aboard centers in Cape Town, South Africa; Delhi, India; Sao Paulo, Brazil; Washington D.C., United States. On this multi country program, students learn how communities around the world understand what it is to achieve and maintain health and well-being.

name: STDABRD 439. CGIS: Health and Community in Argentina, South Africa, Vietnam, and the U.S.
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take classes at the SIT Study Aboard centers in Buenos Aires, Argentina; Cape Town, South Africa; Hanoi, Vietnam; Washington D.C., United States. On this multi country program, students learn how communities around the world understand what it is to achieve and maintain health and well-being.

name: STDABRD 440. CGIS: University Study in Ireland - University College Dublin
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Administered by Arcadia University, this program allows students to enroll in classes at the University College Dublin.

name: STDABRD 441. CGIS: STEM Summer Research Program in Dublin, Ireland
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Administered by Arcadia University, this program allows students to perform STEM research for academic credit with University College Dublin faculty.

name: STDABRD 444. CGIS: STEM Summer Research Program in Aberdeen, Scotland
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students conduct research projects alongside faculty from the University of Aberdeen, Scotland in this Arcadia program.

name: STDABRD 445. CGIS: STEM Summer Research Program in Glasgow, Scotland
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Administered by Arcadia University, this program allows students to perform STEM research for academic credit with University of Glasgow faculty.

name: STDABRD 446. CGIS: Africa in the 21st Century in Accra, Ghana
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students take classes at the SIT Study Abroad center in Accra focused on Africa and more specifically, Ghana, in the 21st century.

name: STDABRD 450. CGIS: University Study in the UK - University of Cambridge, Pembroke College
info: (1 - 1.5). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students direct enroll in 24 credits at Pembroke College. There are no traditional classes at Cambridge University. Rather, Cambridge has the Tripos system, which encompasses three components: lectures, supervisions and exams. Students typically have one supervision per term, attend lectures throughout the terms and take exams at the end of the year.

name: STDABRD 451. CGIS: University Study in the UK - University of Oxford, Hertford College
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Hertford College is part of the University of Oxford system. CGIS has a relationship with Hertford College that allows UM undergraduates to apply to Hertford College as Visiting students. UM students will be considered in-residence at UM while taking courses at Hertford College.

name: STDABRD 452. CGIS: University Study in the UK - University of Oxford, St. Peter's College
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Oxford, England). Su. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students on this summer program take seminars in English Literature, Medieval Studies or Environmental Studies.

name: STDABRD 456. CGIS: University Study in the UK - London School of Economics and Political Science
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (London, England). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at the London School of Economics and Political Science. A wide variety of classes is available.

name: STDABRD 457. CGIS: STEM Summer Research Program in London, United Kingdom
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Administered by Arcadia University, this program allows students to perform STEM research for academic credit with Royal Veterinary College faculty.

name: STDABRD 458. CGIS: University Study in the UK - University of St. Andrews
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (St Andrews, Scotland). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at the University of St. Andrews. A full range of classes is available.

name: STDABRD 460. CGIS:  Study Abroad in Scandinavia (DIS) in Stockholm, Sweden
info: (1 - 15; 1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in one core course and several elective courses offered in a variety of disciplines and taught in English by Danish Institute for Study Abroad (DIS) faculty in Stockholm.

name: STDABRD 461. CGIS: University Study in Sweden - Uppsala University
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Uppsala, Sweden). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at Uppsala University. A full range of classes is available. Classes are taught in English; students with Swedish language proficiency may enroll in regular classes.

name: STDABRD 462. CGIS: University Study in Sweden - Stockholm University
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at Stockholm University. A full range of classes is available. Classes are taught in English; students with Swedish language proficiency may enroll in regular classes.

name: STDABRD 463. CGIS: Central European Studies in Warsaw, Poland
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Prague, Budapest or Warsaw). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: This program is administered by CIEE in Warsaw, Poland at CIEE's Study Center at the Warsaw School of Economics, the oldest and largest economics university in Poland. Students are required to take a mandatory Polish language course and then select other course options taught in English from a range of in such fields as East and Central European politics, literature, history, business and economics.

name: STDABRD 466. CGIS: University Study in Japan - Kyushu University
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Fukuoka, Japan). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Michigan students on this exchange program study Japanese language and take a variety of Japan-related courses, most taught in English.

name: STDABRD 468. CGIS: University Study in Australia - University of New South Wales (Sydney)
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Sydney, Australia). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at the University of New South Wales (UNSW). A full range of classes is available.

name: STDABRD 470. CGIS: STEM Summer Research Program in Brisbane, Australia
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Administered by Arcadia University, this program allows students to perform STEM research for academic credit with the University of Queensland.

name: STDABRD 472. CGIS: University Study in Turkey - Bogazici University (Istanbul)
info: (1 - 15; 1 - 8 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Istanbul, Turkey). Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at Bogazici University in Istanbul. A full range of classes is available. Classes are taught in English.

name: STDABRD 480. CGIS: University Study in the UK - King's College London
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at King's College London, University of London. A full range of classes is available.

name: STDABRD 481. CGIS: University Study in the UK - Queen Mary University in London
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (London, England). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at Queen Mary, University of London. A full range of classes is available.

name: STDABRD 483. CGIS: University Study in the UK - University College London
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (London, England). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at University College London. A full range of classes is available.

name: STDABRD 486. CGIS: University Study in France - Sciences Po Paris
info: Minimum 6 semesters college-level French (or the equivalent). Significant course work in political science or other social science. (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Paris, France). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at the Institut d' Etudes Politiques (Sciences Po) in Paris. A wide range of classes is available. Students must take all courses in French.

name: STDABRD 487. CGIS: University Study in South Africa - University of Cape Town
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Cape Town, South Africa). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at the University of Cape Town (UCT). A full range of classes is available. Classes are taught in English.

name: STDABRD 488. CGIS: Public Health in Cape Town, South Africa
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students examine health care delivery in South Africa through coursework, field visits, observational visits, and service work.

name: STDABRD 489. CGIS: University Study in Australia - University of Melbourne
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 75 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. (Melbourne, Australia). F,W. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at the University of Melbourne. A full range of classes is available.

name: STDABRD 490. CGIS: Health, Culture and Development in Cape Town, South Africa
info: (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in classes at the IES Study Abroad Center in Cape Town, South Africa.

name: STDABRD 491. CGIS: Social Justice and Entrepreneurship at the University of Cape Town, South Africa
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Students enroll in two classes as part of an international consortium at the University of Cape Town.

name: STDABRD 494. CGIS: Language and Culture in Buenos Aires, Argentina
info: Consent of department required. (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: This program is open to students of all language levels interested in studying in Buenos Aires. There is no minimum language requirement for this program, but course options will be dependent on language level placements. Students will enroll in a required 6 credit Spanish language course specifically tailored to their individual level. In addition, students will take IES Abroad area studies courses in English or Spanish. Students may also elect to enroll in a few preselected courses taught in Spanish at two local universities, the Universidad de Ciencias Empresiariales y Sociales and the Instituto Universitario Nacional del Arte (specializes in creative and performing arts). Credit-based internships and service learning opportunities are also available.

name: STDABRD 496. CGIS: Advanced Spanish Language in Buenos Aires, Argentina
info: Minimum 4 semesters college-level Spanish by program start date, fulfilled by: SPANISH 232, SPANISH 230, RCLANG 294, RCLANG 314, or equivalent. (1 - 15). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: Take your Spanish abilities to the next level, through advanced level Spanish courses at the IES Abroad Center in downtown Buenos Aires. Students are required to have five or more semesters of college-level Spanish or the equivalent to study with this program. Specialized workshops focused on academic and creative writing are also available. Students may also select from a wide range and of disciplines and courses in Spanish at one of the following prestigious local universities: Universidad Torcuato di Tella; Universidad de Buenos Aires; Instituto Universitario Nacional de Arte; Universidad de Salvador; and Universidad Ciencias Empresariales y Sociales. Credit-based internships and service learning opportunities are also available.

name: STDABRD 497. CGIS: Multicultural Psychology in Buenos Aires, Argentina
info: (1 - 10 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 60 credits. May be elected more than once in the same term. Multiple Grading Patterns.
description: This immersive experience will provide students with many opportunities for comparison between the US and Argentina, as mental health is a celebrated part of Argentine culture.

name: SURVMETH 605 / SI 400. Design and Implementation of Web Surveys
info: Not required however, SURVMETH 600, Fundamentals of Survey Methodology, will provide a treatment of survey error and survey mode in more depth than this course. May not be repeated for credit.
description:
This is a hands-on course in which small groups of students will develop and deploy a web survey, collect and analyze data from actual respondents, and write a report suitable for a client.
Lectures and class discussion will focus on the scientific literature in web survey methodology with a focus on practical implications.
This course is shared between the University of Michigan and the University of Maryland.
Students from the two universities will sit in different classrooms but attend the same videomediated class/lecture.

name: SW 305. Theories and Practices for Community Action and Social Change
info: Community Action and Social Change Minor declared or interested in declaring. (3). May not be repeated for credit.
description:
This foundations course for the Community Action and Social Change Minor is designed to prepare students to be informed and active participants in the process of community building and social change. The course uses a multidisciplinary framework to develop competencies that will help students envision what community action and social change looks like, identify and implement steps towards social change, build on positive sources of power, indigenous knowledge and experiences of individuals, groups, and communities who are engaged in social change efforts. 
The course material covers theories and practices of community action and social change through an interdisciplinary examination of examples in research and practice. The course focuses on individuals, groups and institutions and how they interact. The course examines empirical quantitative and qualitative studies that test social change methods and provides exposure to and experience with qualitative research methods such as ethnographic observation and interviewing and qualitative data-gathering. Students are engaged in a critical and contrasting assessment of community organizing and other social change methods.

name: THTREMUS 101. Introduction to Acting I
info: Consent of instructor required. Open to non-concentrators. Consent of instructor required. (3). (CE). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 102. Intro to Acting II
info: Consent of instructor required. Consent of instructor. (3). (CE). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 110. Introduction to Acting for the Camera
info: THTREMUS 101 and/or permission of instructor. (3). (CE). May not be repeated for credit.
description: To introduce students to the basic techniques of acting for the camera through the use of video.  Sound foundation acting principles would be presented with an emphasis on exercise, scene and monologue work, and closing with scene orchestration via a basic two-camera with switcher recording, utilizing a mix of selected dramatic material and/or existing film scripts.

name: THTREMUS 211 / ENGLISH 245 / RCHUMS 280. Introduction to Drama and Theatre
info: (3; 2 in the half-term). (HU). May not be repeated for credit. No credit granted to those who have completed or are enrolled in RCHUMS 281.
description: This course aims to introduce students to as many basic aspects of the theatre, practical and theoretical, as time allows.  It also presents them with a number of key plays from various periods and examines them from the point of view of their dramatic qualities, their theatrical strengths, their social and political contexts, their performance history, and their relevance today.

name: THTREMUS 222. Introduction to Global Theatre and Ethnic Studies
info: (3). (HU). May not be repeated for credit.
description: Survey of performance histories of diverse cultural communities of the United States.  Class studies transnational origins and cultural contexts for multi-cultural theater:  African American, Latino/Latin American, Asian American, Middle Eastern and others.

name: THTREMUS 227 / ENGLISH 227. Introductory Playwriting
info: (3; 2 in the half-term). (CE). May not be repeated for credit.
description: A creative writing course in the rudiments of playwriting, with special attention to the one-act play. Students are accepted on the basis of a portfolio.

name: THTREMUS 233. Modern Rituals/Traditional Practices
info: Consent of instructor required. (3). (HU). May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.
description: Trains students in performance techniques grounded in various cultural traditions:  Choral singing, masking, vocal call and response, dance, martial arts, and mimicry.  Embodied studio practice emphasizes the aesthetics of diverse cultural communities.

name: THTREMUS 240. Introduction to Design
info: THTREMUS 250. (3). (CE). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This course introduces students to the process of designing scenery, costumes and lighting for the stage.  It deals both with finding and developing ideas and with finding ways to express them.  It provides students with a process with which to approach to play and begin to design, as well as starting to develop a theatrical vocabulary which will serve as a foundation for future design work.

name: THTREMUS 245. Introduction to Stage Management
info: Permission of instructor. (2 - 3). (CE). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 250. Introduction to Technical Theatre Practices
info: (3; 2 in the half-term). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 251. Practicum I
info: (1). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 252. Prod Practicum II
info: THTREMUS 251 and permission of instructor. (1). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 256. Lighting Design I
info: THTREMUS 250. (3). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This course is an introduction to the components of stage lighting, including an in-depth exploration of the functions and controllable properties of stage lighting.  Some of the topics include color theory, optics, electricity, distribution, and equipment.  Industry standards regarding control systems, organizational standards, and collaborative techniques will also be covered.

name: THTREMUS 260. Scene Design I
info: THTREMUS 250. (3). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This is a beginning course in scenic design with an emphasis on text analysis.  Expression of the production concept, style and period is studied by use of the elements of design.  This includes analyzing and discussing plays as the inspiration for a design, some history of design, considering the three-dimensional world of a stage, and how to make basic drawings and models for a stage design.

name: THTREMUS 261. Practicum III
info: Permission of instructor. (1). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 262. Practicum IV
info: Permission of instructor. (1). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 270. Costume Design I
info: THTREMUS 240 and 277/Permission of instructor. (3). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This course is designed to familiarize students with the art and process of costume design.  There is strong emphasis on text and character analysis as well as methods of research.  An introduction to basic drawing skills is combined with other visual options in presenting design ideas and exploring the collaborative process.

name: THTREMUS 277. History of Dress
info: Permission of instructor. (3). May not be repeated for credit.
description: A slide survey course, which traces the history of dress from ancient times through the present day, with an emphasis in the societies that produced particular manners and styles of dress and their relationship to one another.

name: THTREMUS 321 / ENGLISH 443. History of Theatre I
info: (3). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 322 / ENGLISH 444. History of Theatre II
info: (3). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 323 / ENGLISH 349. American Theatre and Drama
info: (3). (HU). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 324. Global Community Practicum
info: THTREMUS 222. (Prerequisites enforced at registration.) Permission of instructor. (3). May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.
description: This course engages students in research and development of performance projects at a local, community organization or at an international site.  The class participants in field work experiences and each individual submits a final project report or thesis at the end of their fieldwork.  The Capstone course is collaborative and interdisciplinary and multiple faculty members can supervise and approves student work.

name: THTREMUS 325. Contemporary American Theatre and Drama
info: (3). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This course examines works and developments in American theatre and drama from the past twenty years, especially the diverse and multicultural drama of this period.  Looks at elements of class and ethnicity, urbanization, family and community, war and technology, commercialism and consumerism, gender, race, and sexuality.

name: THTREMUS 326. Intercultural Drama
info: Consent of instructor required. (3 in the half-term). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This course examines how international dramatic literature in translation comments on global lives and lifestyles.  Class reads, analyze and discusses intercultural plays in cultural context.  Written assignments and in-class presentations investigate the political, social, ad cultural impact meaning of intercultural dramatic works.

name: THTREMUS 327 / ENGLISH 327. Intermediate Playwriting
info: ENGLISH 227. (3; 2 in the half-term). May not be repeated for credit.
description: Practice in writing short plays.  Conceptualizing a full-length play.

name: THTREMUS 332. Performing Archives and Oral Histories
info: THTREMUS 233 or AAS 342. (Prerequisites enforced at registration.) Permission of instructor. (3 in the half-term). May not be repeated for credit.
description: In this course students use ethnographic or archival sources to create new performance works.  Building on histories introduced in 222, they create individual or small group projects.  Interpretative text and character work helps to improve individual student performance skills.

name: THTREMUS 334 / RCHUMS 332. The Atonement Project
info: (3). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This course will teach students about restorative justice, reconciliation, and atonement.  We will explore questions of why and how artistic activity can begin and/or support processes of reconciliation for people who have committed crimes and for crime victims.  Students in this class will facilitate weekly arts workshops in adult prisons and community venues where former prisoners, crime victims, and the families of those groups can gather together.  Focusing on the themes of acknowledgement, apology, and atonement, the workshops will produce original performances, creative writing, and visual art presented at the end of the semester by both the student facilitators and the members of the workshop.  Students and workshop participants who give their consent can contribute their work to the Atonement Project website - an online forum designed by the MIT Media Lab - as a means of starting conversations about atonement with web users.  Ultimately this course seeks to identify the best strategies for using the arts to address crime and those most affected by it.

name: THTREMUS 335 / RCHUMS 335. Theatre and Incarceration
info: May not be repeated for credit.
description: Artistic practice in prisons has occurred since the inception of prisons themselves, though popular thought tends not to connect the idea of the arts with that criminal justice systems.  This course surveys the history of performance in prisons through the examination of plays written by and about prisoners as well as narratives which chronicle the process of creating theatre in prisons.  The course also interrogates various strategies for creating performances in prisons, questioning the utility and goals of each process of creation and seeking to identify those which are most sustainable and which best serve participants in the process.  Students will use some of these strategies in practice as they facilitate their workshops in prisons and juvenile detention centers.

name: THTREMUS 340. Devising Theatre
info: Permission of instructor. (3 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.
description: This course is a laboratory course for play development.  The class creates collaborative theatrical works from text, visual art, movement, stories and/or contemporary events.  The class develops performances through improvisation, then organizes and evaluates their work using principles of dramatic structure, and play analysis.  Dramaturgy and directing skills are introduced through studio practice and critique.

name: THTREMUS 345. Stage Management-Plays
info: Consent of instructor required. THTREMUS 351 & permission of instructor. (2 - 6). May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.
description: This course covers methods of stage management including rehearsal coordination, prompt book preparation, record keeping, and director, cast and crew relationships during the rehearsal period.

name: THTREMUS 350. Scenic Constructn I
info: THTREMUS 250&362/P.I. (3). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 351. Practicum V
info: Permission of instructor. (1 - 3). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 352. Practicum VI
info: Permission of instructor. (1 - 3). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 353. Sound for Theatre
info: Consent of instructor required. Consent of instructor required. THTREMUS 250&P.I. (2). May be elected five times for credit. W.
description: Students work as a member of a theatre production team with emphasis on sound effects and sound design for theatre.

name: THTREMUS 356. Lighting Design II
info: Consent of instructor required. Consent of instructor required. THTREMUS 256/P.I. (3). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This course features an in-depth exploration into the development and execution of lighting design, including an extensive exploration into the lighting potentials of a wide variety of facilities, production styles, and lighting equipment.  It works on the development of communication skills with directors and shops via value sketches, plots, and paperwork.

name: THTREMUS 360. Scene Design II
info: Consent of instructor required. Consent of instructor required. THTREMUS 260/P.I. (3). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This course is intended for students who would like to gain more experience with scenic design and for those whose main area of interest is scenic design.  Some advanced model-making and drawing skills will be dealt with, but more time will be spent on the process of conceptualizing and articulating design ideas.  Students will also explore the unique characteristics of proscenium, arena, and thrust staging.

name: THTREMUS 385 / ARTSADMN 385. Performing Arts Management
info: Consent of instructor required. (2). May not be repeated for credit.
description: An introduction and overview of management issues concerning the non-profit cultural sector.

name: THTREMUS 386. Prac Perfor Art Mgt
info: Consent of instructor required. PER. INSTR. (3). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 399. Topics in Drama
info: (1 - 4). May be repeated for credit.
description: This course covers specialized topics in theatre and drama, which vary from semester to semester.  The purpose is to explore in depth aspects of the theatre that cannot be covered in existing courses, such as a play or special subject.

name: THTREMUS 400. Directed Reading
info: Consent of instructor required. Undergraduate standing; and consent of instructor. (1 - 3). (INDEPENDENT). May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.

name: THTREMUS 401. Independent Study
info: Consent of instructor required. PER. INSTR. (1 - 3). (INDEPENDENT). May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.

name: THTREMUS 402. Ideas of Theatre

name: THTREMUS 403. Des&Prod Seminar
info: Permission of instructor / non-majors. (1). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 404. Des&Prod Seminar
info: Permission of instructor / non-majors. (1). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 427 / ENGLISH 427. Advanced Playwriting
info: Consent of instructor required. ENGLISH 327. (3; 2 in the half-term). May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.
description: Students write a full-length play. Skills are developed through technique assignments, rewrites, class readings and discussions, viewing of local plays.

name: THTREMUS 429. Playwr Production
info: Consent of instructor required. THTREMUS 327/P.I. (3). May not be repeated for credit. W.

name: THTREMUS 440. Special Topics in African American Theatre and Drama
info: THTREMUS 222. (3 in the half-term). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This is a special topics course, which address various aspects of African American Theatre and Drama, such as:  Comparing Black Aesthetics, African American Dramatic Literature, and Traditions and Modernity in African Drama.

name: THTREMUS 445. Stage Management:  Music/Opera
info: Consent of instructor required. THTREMUS 351 and permission of instructor. (2 - 6). May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.
description: This course covers methods of stage managment including rehearsal coordination, prompt book or musical score preparation, record keeping, and director, conductor / orchestra, cast and crew relationships during the rehearsal period.

name: THTREMUS 452. Costume Construction
info: Consent of instructor required. Permission of instructor. (3). May not be repeated for credit. W.

name: THTREMUS 462. Drafting
info: Consent of instructor required. THTREMUS 250. (3). May not be repeated for credit. No credit granted to those who have completed or are enrolled in THTREMUS 362. Undergraduates must elect THTREMUS 362.

name: THTREMUS 464. Sc Paint for Theatr
info: THTREMUS 250. (3). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 466. History of Decor
info: Permission of instructor. (3). May not be repeated for credit. W.
description: This course is a chronological study of the decorative styles of interiors and exteriors in Western architecture and their applications to the stage.

name: THTREMUS 468. History of Theatre Architecture
info: Permission of instructor. (3). May not be repeated for credit.

name: THTREMUS 471. Women's Pattern Drafting
info: Consent of instructor required. Permission of instructor. (3). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This experiential craft course covers the techniques for drafting women's slopers based on standard measurements.  Using basic bodice, sleeve, and skirt slopers students develop patterns for contemporary and historical garments.  Students investigate dart and seam manipulation to produce patterns, and then make and fit muslin mockups.  Final projects could include developing patterns from the garments in the Zelma Weisfeld Historic Collection or patterning garments for a Theatre Departmental production.

name: THTREMUS 476. Costume Crafts
info: Consent of instructor required. Permission of instructor. (3). May not be repeated for credit.
description: An introduction to the materials and techniques used in the design and construction of craft work associated with theatrical costumes.  Specific topics explored include millinery, mask making and dyeing and painting of fabric.  Class consists of lectures and demonstrations providing a survey of possible techniques and materials as well as specific projects designed to develop practical skills.

name: TO 518 / IOE 510 / MATH 561. Linear Programming I
info: MATH 217, 417, or 419. (3). (BS). May not be repeated for credit.
description: Formulation of problems from the private and public sectors using the mathematical model of linear programming.  Development of the simplex algorithm; duality theory and economic interpretations.  Postoptimality (sensitivity) analysis application and interpretations.  Introduction to transportation and assignment problems; special purpose algorithms and advanced computational techniques.  Students have opportunities to formulate and solve models developed from more complex case studies and to use various computer programs.

name: TURKISH 101. Elementary Turkish I
info: (4). May not be repeated for credit. No credit granted to those who have completed or are enrolled in TURKISH 103 (AAPTIS 155).
description: An introduction to Turkish language, this course aims to equip students with a basic understanding of Turkish grammar, pronunciation, vocabulary, and culture.

name: TURKISH 102. Elementary Turkish II
info: TURKISH 101 (AAPTIS 151) or equivalent. (4). May not be repeated for credit. No credit granted to those who have completed or are enrolled in TURKISH 103 (AAPTIS 155).

name: TURKISH 201. Intermediate Turkish I
info: TURKISH 102 (AAPTIS 152) or TURKISH 103 (AAPTIS 155). (4). May not be repeated for credit. No credit granted to those who have completed or are enrolled in TURKISH 203 (AAPTIS 255).
description: Part of the department sequence in modern Turkish, this course will be an immediate continuation of Elementary Turkish II. The aim is to further improve proficiency skills in listening, speaking, reading and writing.

name: TURKISH 202. Intermediate Turkish II
info: TURKISH 201 (AAPTIS 251). (4). (Lang Req). May not be repeated for credit. No credit granted to those who have completed or are enrolled in TURKISH 203 (AAPTIS 255).

name: TURKISH 407. Readings in Ottoman Turkish
info: TURKISH 406. (3). May be elected twice for credit.
description: This course is for students who have completed the sequence of TURKISH 405 and 406. Readings and assignments will continue to build on the Ottoman Turkish skills acquired in these two courses.

name: TURKISH 410. Topics in Turkish Language
info: Advanced Turkish proficiency or permission of instructor. (3). May be elected three times for credit.
description: This course is aimed at undergraduate and graduate students with advanced Turkish language proficiency. Topics will vary, focusing on aspects of culture, linguistics, literature, music, religion, film, history, etc. All material will be in Turkish, and the class will be taught in Turkish.

name: TURKISH 499. Independent Study in Turkish
info: Consent of department required. (1 - 4). (INDEPENDENT). May be elected three times for credit. May be elected more than once in the same term.
description: An independent study course in the area of Turkish language. The intended language of instruction is Turkish. Approval from the department is required.

name: TURKISH 504. Modern Turkish Readings and Communication
info: TURKISH 202 (AAPTIS 252) or TURKISH 203 (AAPTIS 255). (3). May be elected three times for credit.
description: Intensive linguistic practice in modern Turkish with thorough literary, historical, and philological analysis.

name: UC 101 / NAVSCI 102. Seapower and Maritime Affairs
info: (2). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This course focuses on the historical role of sea power, emphasizing the U.S. Navy. Topics include: development of naval power and applications as an instrument of foreign policy; historical relationship of navies with their respective domestic, political, and economic environments; and the rise of the U.S. as a maritime power.

name: UC 110 / SI 110. Introduction to Information Studies
info: (4). (SS). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This course will provide the foundational knowledge necessary to begin to address the key issues associated with the Information Revolution.  Issues will range from the theoretical (what is information and how do humans construct it?), to the cultural (is life on the screen a qualitatively different phenomenon from experiences with earlier distance-shrinking and knowledge-building technologies such as telephones?), to the practical (what are the basic architecture of computing networks?).  Successful completion of this "gateway" course will give you the conceptual tools for an initial understanding of the politics, economics, and culture of the Information Age, providing a foundation for later study in Information or any number of other disciplines.  You will be more thoughtful about thorny information issues, and more "information literate" than you were before.

name: UC 150. First-Year Humanities Seminar
info: Enrollment restricted to first-year students, including those with sophomore standing. (3). (HU). May not be repeated for credit.
description: Designed to introduce entering students to the intellectual life of the university in a small course taught by an experienced member of the faculty. Topics vary according to the interests of the instructors. Whatever their subject matter, first-year seminars emphasize critical thinking through class discussion and regular practice in writing. UC 150, UC 151, UC 152, and UC 153 differ only in their area distribution designation.

name: UC 151. First-Year Social Science Seminar
info: Enrollment restricted to first-year students, including those with sophomore standing. (3). (SS). May not be repeated for credit.
description: Designed to introduce entering students to the intellectual life of the university in a small course taught by an experienced member of the faculty. Topics vary according to the interests of the instructors. Whatever their subject matter, first-year seminars emphasize critical thinking through class discussion and regular practice in writing.

name: UC 152. First-Year Natural Science Seminar
info: Enrollment restricted to first-year students, including those with sophomore standing. (3). (NS). (BS). May not be repeated for credit.
description: Designed to introduce entering students to the intellectual life of the university in a small course taught by an experienced member of the faculty. Topics vary according to the interests of the instructors. Whatever their subject matter, first-year seminars emphasize critical thinking through class discussion and regular practice in writing.

name: UC 154. First-Year Interdisciplinary Seminar
info: Enrollment restricted to first-year students, including those with sophomore standing. (3). (ID). May not be repeated for credit.
description: Designed to introduce entering students to the intellectual life of the university in a small course taught by an experienced member of the faculty. Topics vary according to the interests of the instructors. Whatever their subject matter, first-year seminars emphasize critical thinking through class discussion and regular practice in writing.

name: UC 163. Biotechnology and Human Values
info: First-year students only. (4). (NS). (BS). May not be repeated for credit.
description: The primary purpose of this course is to teach a basic vocabulary in biotechnology and expose students to the breadth of biotechnology and its impact on our daily lives. Topics will cover a broad range of applications in genetics, molecular diagnostics, molecular imaging, and clinical devices. A key additional component will be to investigate human values issues, such as ethical questions and cost effectiveness, arising from these technologies.

name: UC 170. UC Special Topics
info: (1 - 3). May be elected three times for credit. May be elected more than once in the same term. Offered mandatory credit/no credit.
description: This course is intended to house interdisciplinary courses that do not fit into any specific department or courses taught by non-LSA faculty from various units across the university.

name: UC 201 / AERO 201. Team and Leadership Fundamentals I
info: AERO 102/Permission of Instructor. (1). May not be repeated for credit. (non-LSA credit).
description: Topics allow students to improve their leadership personally and within teams, instill a leadership mindset and transition from cadet to officer candidate. The course prepares students for field-training, where they will put concepts into practice

name: UC 202 / AERO 202. Team and Leadership Fundamentals II
info: AERO 201/Permission of Instructor. (1). May not be repeated for credit. (non-LSA credit).
description: Topics allow students to improve their leadership personally and within teams, instill a leadership mindset and transition from cadet to officer candidate. The course prepares students for field-training, where they will put concepts into practice.

name: UC 203 / MILSCI 201. Innovative Tactical Leadership
info: (1). May not be repeated for credit. Counts as credit toward LSA degree.
description: This course considers military government leadership with a focus on leadership development and interpersonal and group dynamics. It explores the dimensions of creative and innovative tactical leadership strategies and styles through lecture, historical case studies, and interactive student exercises.

name: UC 204 / MILSCI 202. Leadership in Changing Environments
info: Permission of professor. (1). May not be repeated for credit. Counts as credit toward LSA degree.
description: This course examines the challenges of leading in complex contemporary operational environments.  Dimensions of the cross-cultural challenges of leadership in a constantly changing world are highlighted and applied to practical Army leadership tasks and situations.

name: UC 205 / NAVSCI 203. Leadership and Management
info: NAVSCI 101,102 OR PI. (3). May not be repeated for credit.
description: This course is specifically designed to teach introductory-level leadership and management concepts and applications to sophomore-level university students.
